what: gsm.qtl – Introduction to Quality Tolerance Limit (QTL) Analysis
title: IntroQTL
text: gsm.qtl package specialized module within Gilead Statistical Monitoring (GSM) framework, focusing Quality Tolerance Limit (QTL) analysis. designed detect atypical trends metric study-level indication potential data integrity patient safety concerns using pre-specified data-driven thresholds.

previous_headings: gsm.qtl – Introduction to Quality Tolerance Limit (QTL) Analysis
title: IntroQTL
text: gsm.qtl mirrors modular design GSM ecosystem. typical workflow includes: Data Ingestion Load participant-level trial data (e.g., deviations). Summarization Aggregate data study‑level metrics rates deviations, etc. Threshold Detection Compare study’s metrics QTL thresholds using: Z‑score calculations optional overdispersion adjustments Flagging Assign risk levels (Red / Green) based breaches thresholds. Visualization & Reporting Produce interactive HTML reports charts, summary tables, filters exploration.

previous_headings: gsm.qtl – Introduction to Quality Tolerance Limit (QTL) Analysis
title: IntroQTL
text: Modular & Compliant Leverages qualified GSM statistical engine unit testing familiar reports/outputs. Flexible Thresholds Supports static QTLs (predefined YAML) data-driven cutoffs (z-scores, quantiles). End--End Reporting Generates clean, reproducible outputs can embedded trial oversight reports.

previous_headings: gsm.qtl – Introduction to Quality Tolerance Limit (QTL) Analysis
title: IntroQTL
text: default statistical method applies normal approximation binomial distribution binary outcome dynamic thresholds. method particularly useful monitoring binary outcomes, proportion participants eligibility-related deviations early study discontinuation, goal identify studies deviate significantly expected rates. study, proportion metric calculated p̂=numdenom, \hat{p} = \frac{\text{num}}{\text{denom}}, num number observed events interest (e.g., participants protocol deviations related eligibility, early study discontinuation) denom relevant denominator (e.g., total participants). observed proportion compared predefined QTL threshold calculated following. expected mean QTL, p0p_0, typically derived historical trial data (e.g., 0.05). expected mean, p0p_0, configurable workflows study study, denoted nPropRate analysis yaml’s meta field. account natural variability, tolerance margin added threshold based normal approximation binomial distribution: Tolerance Margin=z×p0(1−p0)denom. \text{Tolerance Margin} = \text{z} \times \sqrt{\frac{p_0(1 - p_0)}{\text{denom}}}. , zz, also configurable denoted nNumDeviations yaml’s meta field, controls leniency threshold. excursion QTL limit flagged p̂>p0+z×p0(1−p0)denom. \hat{p} > p_0 + \text{z} \times \sqrt{\frac{p_0(1 - p_0)}{\text{denom}}}. approach conceptually similar one-sided control limit around expected rate p0p_0. Studies exceeding adjusted limit flagged review potential outliers monitored metric.

what: Good Statistical Monitoring QTL {gsm.qtl} R package
title: Good Statistical Monitoring QTLs
text: README provides high-level overview gsm.qtl; see package website additional details. Good Statistical Monitoring gsm suite R packages provides framework statistical data monitoring. gsm.qtl extension package contains additional functions, workflows, document template generate reports quality tolerance limits (QTL). See gsm.core overview ecosystem.

title: Good Statistical Monitoring QTLs
text: gsm.qtl package calculates study level metrics can represented sort M/N value used evaluate particular QTL particular study, inclusion/exclusion criteria violations, early study discontinuation, etc.

title: Good Statistical Monitoring QTLs
text: Datasets necessary calculate particular QTL can requested customized based previously existing mappings, see gsm.mapping. Additional mappings added support gsm.qtl include IE EXCLUSION mappings.

title: Good Statistical Monitoring QTLs
text: qtlxxxx metric yaml files added calculate study level QTLs, files follow similar structure found gsm.kri.

title: Good Statistical Monitoring QTLs
text: gsm.qtl report template produce data visualizations, widgets tables ultimately go html QTL report.

title: Good Statistical Monitoring QTLs
text: can install development version gsm.qtl like :

title: Good Statistical Monitoring QTLs
text: basic example showing create interactive widget visualizations based reporting outputs gsm.reporting package:
code: library(gsm.datasim) library(gsm.mapping) library(gsm.reporting) library(gsm.core) library(gsm.kri) library(purrr) library(dplyr) library(gsm.qtl) set.seed(1234)  # Single Study ie_data <- generate_rawdata_for_single_study(   SnapshotCount = 6,   SnapshotWidth = "months",   ParticipantCount = 1000,   SiteCount = 10,   StudyID = "ABC",   workflow_path = "workflow/1_mappings",   mappings = c("IE", "PD", "STUDCOMP"),   package = "gsm.mapping",   desired_specs = NULL )  mappings_wf <- gsm.core::MakeWorkflowList(   strNames =c("SUBJ", "ENROLL", "IE", "PD", "STUDY", "SITE", "COUNTRY", "EXCLUSION", "STUDCOMP"),   strPath = "workflow/1_mappings",   strPackage = "gsm.mapping" ) mappings_spec <- gsm.mapping::CombineSpecs(mappings_wf) metrics_wf <- gsm.core::MakeWorkflowList(strNames = c("qtl0001", "qtl0002"), strPath = "inst/workflow/2_metrics", strPackage = "gsm.qtl") reporting_wf <- gsm.core::MakeWorkflowList(strNames = c("Results", "Groups"), strPath = "workflow/3_reporting", strPackage = "gsm.reporting")  lRaw <- map_depth(ie_data, 1, gsm.mapping::Ingest, mappings_spec) mapped <- map_depth(lRaw, 1, ~ gsm.core::RunWorkflows(mappings_wf, .x)) analyzed <- map_depth(mapped, 1, ~gsm.core::RunWorkflows(metrics_wf, .x)) reporting <- map2(mapped, analyzed, ~ gsm.core::RunWorkflows(reporting_wf, c(.x, list(lAnalyzed = .y, lWorkflows = metrics_wf))))  dates <- names(ie_data) %>% as.Date reporting <- map2(reporting, dates, ~{   .x$Reporting_Results$SnapshotDate <- .y   .x })  # Bind multiple snapshots of data together all_reportingResults <- do.call(dplyr::bind_rows, lapply(reporting, function(x) x$Reporting_Results))    # Only need 1 reporting group object all_reportingGroups <- reporting[[length(reporting)]]$Reporting_Groups  report_listings <- list(qtl0001 = mapped$`2012-06-30`$Mapped_EXCLUSION,                         qtl0002 = left_join(mapped$`2012-06-30`$Mapped_STUDCOMP,                                             select(mapped$`2012-06-30`$Mapped_SUBJ, subjid, country),                                             by = "subjid"))  # Test if new Report_QTL rmd works gsm.kri::RenderRmd(   lParams = list(     dfResults = all_reportingResults,     dfGroups = all_reportingGroups,     lListings = report_listings   ),   strOutputDir = getwd(),   strOutputFile = "test.html",   strInputPath = system.file("report/Report_QTL.Rmd", package = "gsm.qtl") )

what: Funnel Plot Analysis with Normal Approximation for Binary and Rate Outcomes. — Analyze_OneSideProp
title: Funnel Plot Analysis with Normal Approximation for Binary and Rate Outcomes. — Analyze_OneSideProp
text: Creates analysis results data percentage/rate data using funnel plot method normal approximation.

title: Funnel Plot Analysis with Normal Approximation for Binary and Rate Outcomes. — Analyze_OneSideProp
Funnel Plot Analysis with Normal Approximation for Binary and Rate Outcomes. — Analyze_OneSideProp
text: dfTransformed data.frame Transformed data analysis. Data one record per site expected columns: GroupID, GroupLevel, Numerator, Denominator, Metric. details see Data Model vignette: vignette("DataModel", package = "gsm.core"). function, dfTransformed typically created using gsm.core::Transform_Rate(). nPropRate numeric, 0 1, represents proportion comparison, e.g. historic screen failure rate nNumDeviations numeric, e.g. '3', standard deviations away value provided nPropRate calculate threshold Metric flagged

title: Funnel Plot Analysis with Normal Approximation for Binary and Rate Outcomes. — Analyze_OneSideProp
text: data.frame one row per study columns: GroupID, GroupLevel, Numerator, Denominator, Metric, Flag two rows upper-funnel nPropRate flatline instead

title: Funnel Plot Analysis with Normal Approximation for Binary and Rate Outcomes. — Analyze_OneSideProp
text: function applies funnel plots using fixed proportion/rate number standard deviations according one-sided Z proportion test.

title: Funnel Plot Analysis with Normal Approximation for Binary and Rate Outcomes. — Analyze_OneSideProp
code: # Binary dftransformed <- tibble::tribble(   ~GroupID, ~GroupLevel, ~Numerator, ~Denominator, ~Metric,   "ABC", "Study", 25, 100, 0.25 )  dfAnalyzed <- Analyze_OneSideProp(dftransformed, nPropRate = 0.01, nNumDeviations = 3)

text: dfResults results data.frame output gsm.reporting::BindResults() used create variety visualizations like line plot, bar plot. dfMetrics results data.frame output gsm.reporting::MakeMetric() dfGroups groups data.frame output Groups.yaml gsm.reportingused create variety visualizations like line plot, bar plot. lListings list data.frames used listings represent participants numerators visualizations dfResults. strOutputDir output directory path generated report. provided, report saved current working directory. strOutputFile output file name generated report. provided, report named based study ID, Group Level Date. strInputPath Path template report

what: Compute a widget height from the number of y-axis groups — calc_fig_size
title: Compute a widget height from the number of y-axis groups — calc_fig_size
text: Convenience helper HTML widgets (e.g., Plotly) converts count categories/rows pixel height. function returns larger base per * n_rows, keeps small plots readable allowing tall plots many groups shown.

title: Compute a widget height from the number of y-axis groups — calc_fig_size
Compute a widget height from the number of y-axis groups — calc_fig_size
text: n_rows single non-negative number giving number rows/groups (e.g., distinct y-axis categories). base Minimum height pixels allocate regardless n_rows. Default 500. per Height pixels allocate per row/group. Default 22.

title: Compute a widget height from the number of y-axis groups — calc_fig_size
text: integer pixel value suitable widget's height = argument.
